channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing : Germany: The Flight of the Iguana
item.description: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week.
item.dc:creator: By ALISON SMALE

item.title: The Lede: Images of Turkish Official Kicking Protester Fuel Anger Online
item.description: The behavior of senior officials in Turkey remained under the social media microscope on Thursday, as an aide to the prime minister acknowledged that he did kick a protester the day before.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Yusuf Yerkel, an aide to Turkey's prime minister, was photographed kicking a man during protests on Wednesday in the city of Soma.

item.title: Talks on Ukraine Crisis Move to Separatist Region
item.description: Ukrainian officials on Saturday held more negotiations aimed at ending the country’s political crisis, this time in the region torn by pro-Russian separatism.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN

item.title: Death Toll in Turkish Mine Disaster Hits 299 as New Fire Breaks Out
item.description: The new fire in the mine hindered efforts to find three workers who were still believed to trapped there.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU and GERRY MULLANY
item.media:description: Rescued workers carried a body of miner to an ambulance in Soma, Turkey, Friday night.

item.title: Crash in Laos Kills Top Government Officials
item.description: Two key figures in the security apparatus of the authoritarian government were among those killed, Laotian diplomats said.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER

item.title: India Ink: Congress’s Rank and File Lament Demise of Party Once Beloved
item.description: Theories abound for the Indian National Congress’s reversal of fortunes, but workers gathered at the party headquarters during the vote count said the culture of the leadership had changed.
item.dc:creator: By SUHASINI RAJ

item.title: World Briefing: Haiti: American Missionary Killed
item.description: An American missionary in his 70s who had moved to Haiti in the wake of the 2010 earthquake was stabbed to death in Port-au-Prince, the capital, the police and friends said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing : Bangladesh: Ferry Death Toll Rises
item.description: A ferry that capsized during a storm in central Bangladesh, killing at least 29 people and possibly many more, was probably overcrowded when it went down on Thursday, the authorities said Friday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing: Pakistan: Boy Kills a Jailed Man Who Was Accused of Blasphemy
item.description: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy.
item.dc:creator: By WAQAR GILLANI

item.title: Jean-Luc Dehaene, Former Prime Minister of Belgium, Is Dead at 73
item.description: Mr. Dehaene, a member of the Flemish Christian Democratic Party, became prime minister in March 1992.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM YARDLEY

item.title: Key Figure in Libya’s Revolution Leads Attack on Islamists
item.description: A former general gained support from members of the army in eastern Libya and killed two dozen people in and around Benghazi, according to news reports.
item.dc:creator: By SULIMAN ALI ZWAY and CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Quick History: Democracy Triumphs in India, but Falters Again in Ukraine
item.description: An orderly, large-scale election contrasts with crises in Ukraine, Thailand and Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: By SERGE SCHMEMANN
item.media:description: People waited to cast their votes on Monday at a polling station in Jaunpur, in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh, India.

item.title: The Lede: British Candidate Clarifies Just Which Immigrants Disturb Him
item.description: In a contentious radio interview, a British nationalist politician from an anti-immigrant party denied being racist.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Unrest Poses a Risky Choice for Vietnam
item.description: As Vietnam’s government deals with the fallout from a week of violence aimed at foreign businesses, it risks angering both residents and investors.
item.dc:creator: By CHRIS BUCKLEY and EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Chinese workers from the Formosa Steel mill who where injured when anti-Chinese protests in Vietnam became violent.

item.title: Narendra Modi’s Ambitious Agenda Will Face Difficult Obstacles
item.description: The Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party’s enormous victory clearly reflects a rapid change in Indian society as urbanization and economic growth break down old voting patterns.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Kuni Takahashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Narendra Modi’s opposition party celebrated in New Delhi on Friday. The governing party, the Indian National Congress, received a crushing defeat.

item.title: Colombia and Rebels Agree on Drug Fight
item.description: Negotiators for the government and the FARC guerrillas announced their pact, part of broader talks, just a week before a presidential election.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Abbas Meets in London With Israeli Negotiator
item.description: The president of the Palestinian Authority spoke with Israel’s justice minister in the first known face-to-face talks between the two sides since peace negotiations collapsed last month.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Swiss Prepare to Vote on World’s Highest Minimum Wage
item.description: The minimum would be set at $24.65 an hour in an effort to address inequalities.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Nuclear Talks With Iran Fail to Yield Pact, Officials Say
item.description: Both sides call the talks slow and difficult, and say that gaps remain on the size of enrichment capability Iran would be permitted.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER

item.title: For India’s Persecuted Muslim Minority, Caution Follows Hindu Party’s Victory
item.description: After a landslide electoral triumph by Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist party, some Muslims said they were worried their place in India could become even more tenuous.
item.dc:creator: By GARDINER HARRIS
item.media:description: Muslim women with a portrait of Narendra Modi, the candidate from the Bharatiya Janata Party, on Friday in Varanasi. Allies say there is no reason for Muslims to fear a government led by him.

item.title: Public’s Outrage Over Mine Disaster Casts Harsh Light on Turkey’s Premier
item.description: The accident has metastasized from a local tragedy into a new political crisis for Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan, who has aggravated public outrage with highhanded remarks.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO, KAREEM FAHIM, SEBNEM ARS and U
item.media:description: Miners departed during a break from their search and rescue operation for colleagues trapped after a mining disaster in Soma.

item.title: Russian Rocket Crashes After Takeoff
item.description: A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a communications satellite crashed in Kazakhstan after what appeared to have been an engine malfunction, an official said.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW ROTH

item.title: Explosions Kill 10 in Kenya as Western Embassies Warn of Threats
item.description: The blasts struck a market in Nairobi, and two suspects have been arrested, the authorities said, but no group has claimed responsibility.
item.dc:creator: By ISMA’IL KUSHKUSH
item.media:description: A crowd gathers in Nairobi where twin explosions claimed lives.

item.title: India Ink: Live-Blogging the Vote Count in India
item.description: India Ink is following the Indian election results throughout the day.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A supporter holding up a placard bearing the portrait of J. Jayalalithaa, chief minister of Tamil Nadu, during celebrations in Chennai, Tamil Nadu on Friday.

item.title: The Saturday Profile: Baghdad Is a Setting, and a Character, Too
item.description: Ahmed Saadawi, who won a top Arabic literary prize, is at the vanguard of a group of writers starting to interpret the trauma of a decade of war.
item.dc:creator: By TIM ARANGO
item.media:credit: Max Becherer for The New York Times
item.media:description: The author Ahmed Saadawi in the al-Bataween district of Baghdad, where his award-winning novel, “Frankenstein in Baghdad,” is set.
